Award.AwardTitle: Resonant microfluidic circuits for assay automation and detection in point-of-care diagnostics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Lutz, Barry
Institution: University Of Washington

Intellectual Merit: The field of microfluidics aims to create portable "laboratories" to carry out analytical tests. Devices are typically simple polymer cards that require supporting equipment to control fluids (e.g., pumps, valves, controllers) and detect test results (e.g., imaging). A key challenge for point-of-use medical diagnostics, environmental monitoring, bio-threat detection, etc. is reducing the expense and physical burden of the instrumentation. Nearly everyone has a cell phone that could serve as a test instrument- they are ubiquitous, battery-powered, easy-to-use-and they are capable of generating, detecting, and communicating information-rich audio signals. We envision a disposable test card connected to a phone earbud, where audio tones (1) control fluidic steps by "talking" to the card, and (2) quantify test results by "listening" to the output from the card. The principle is based on a classic analogy between electrical and fluidic circuits. In electrical circuits, useful functions are created via simple combinations of resistors, inductors, capacitors, and diodes (e.g., a radio tuner). By using oscillating flows in microscale channels ("AC microfluidics"), we can resurrect functions that we know from electrical circuits. This proposal aims to develop AC microfluidic circuits that perform analytical functions for point-of-use testing. Fluidic versions of classic electrical circuits will be created (e.g., band-pass filters), and measurements of the fluidic circuit frequency response will be compared to electrical circuit models. A "microphone" will be incorporated into cards to measure circuit output, and audio-based sensing circuits will be developed via model-based design and experimental validation. Signal transduction chemistries will be developed that produce physical changes in a circuit component, and the system will be used to detect a malarial biomarker.

Broader Impacts: The grant will support student projects in the cross-disciplinary field of global health diagnostics, which offers rich educational experiences that require integration of engineering with broader issues of health, culture, ethics, regulatory procedures, and commercialization in low-resource settings. The global health focus also introduces unique constraints on engineering (simplicity, cost, ease-of-use) that often require creative and simple solutions. Technology for global health needs will be highlighted in public outreach including hands-on exhibition at our annual Engineering Open House. Undergraduate students will participate in design projects to develop card-to-phone interfaces and cell phone "apps" for on-phone data analysis, and the PI will host a group of students in the laboratory as part of the UW STEM Bridge program that aims to encourage underrepresented students to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Resonant microfluidic circuits for assay automation and detection in point-of-care diagnostics

PI: Barry Lutz, University of Washington, Department of Bioengineering

Students: Rahil Jain, Reid Philips, Doan Dinh, Annapurni Sriram, Rachana Shah, Yoni Browning

Collaborators: Peter Kauffman, Bruce Darling, Nathan White

The vision is to develop physical principles that allow cell phone audio to control fluidic movement in microfluidic point-of-care diagnostics and detect the results of biochemical tests carried out on the devices. The principles are based on the analogy between fluidic systems and electrical circuits, where the fluidic components represent resistors, inductors, capacitors, and diodes that can be used to design sophisticated "fluidic circuits".  

Under the NSF grant, we reported the first direct comparisons of flow magnitude and phase measurements to a model based on conventional RLC electrical circuits, and we showed that complex multi-channel microfluidic networks followed model predictions.  Thus, we have established the hydraulic analogy holds even for complex circuits, which opens the door to design to new microfluidic designs.  

Outcome 1. We showed that resonant oscillating flow could be rectified by a passive valve, and that the peak in pumping occurred at the resonance of oscillating flow.  We used this understanding to design three-channel pump networks that allowed each pump to be selected by a different audio tone. This work was published in Lab on a Chip and highlighted as an Editor’s Choice article in Science Translational Medicine.

Outcome 2. As a by-product of that work, we tested a different valve design that we found had a surprising behavior - the direction of pumping could be reversed by excitation at two different frequencies, and these frequencies corresponded to the series resonance and parallel resonance of the microfluidic circuit. This work was published in Lab on a Chip and was the front cover image for that journal issue.

Outcome 3. We aimed to demonstrate the depth of the hydraulic analogy so that others could see the potential to design complex microfluidic circuits.  We developed novel methods to measure both magnitude and phase measurements, and made detailed comparisons to model predictions for series and parallel RLC circuits. This work was published in Analytical Methods and was the front cover image for that journal issue.

Outcome 4. We also demonstrated two exemplary analytical methods in multi-channel microfluidic networks - a Fourier analysis and a pulse analysis.  These circuits show that each channel responds to its fundamental frequency via its fluidic resonance. This work has been submitted to a peer-reviewed journal.

The project is at the intersection of physical science and health technology, specifically in the area of point-of-care diagnostics. The use of cell phones for diagnosis is a concept that resonates (no pun intended) with a general audience and draws their attention to global health needs and the potential role of technology to address global health problems. In addition, we hope that, beyond direct technology impact, this work will inspire new ideas from researchers working to improve health. Students working on this project developed an outreach activity based on this project. They developed two parts presented together: 1) demonstration of audio-controlled circuits by asking visitors to sing tones into a microphone driving a fluidic device, and when they hit the right tone, the fluid oscillates rapidly ("dances"), and 2) turning a knob on a sine wave generator to identify the resonant frequency of three devices filled with three fluids of different viscosity (which changes the resonant properties). These are titled as the "Aqua Singer" and the "Aqua Detective". Students participated in many outreach activities including the University of Washington Engineering Open House, Bioengineering Summer Camp, a local high school AP Biology Program, and Innovation Days at the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.
